document.title: Ma stack de 2023 pour le développement web.
document.summary: Moi qui avais commencé avec PHP et MySQL à mes débuts, j'ai fini par me tourner vers JavaScript et ses frameworks.

body.raw:
## Mes débuts

Quand j’ai commencé à coder, PHP et MySQL étaient mes outils de prédilection. Je créais des sites web dynamiques basiques, et à cette époque, cela me paraissait révolutionnaire. J’ai appris à structurer une base de données, écrire des requêtes SQL, et gérer des formulaires avec PHP. Ces compétences ont été les fondations solides de ma carrière dans le développement web.

## Pourquoi JavaScript

Avec le temps, j’ai commencé à explorer JavaScript. Ce langage m’a permis d’ajouter de l’interactivité à mes applications, et rapidement, il est devenu le pivot de mon stack de développement. Aujourd’hui, grâce aux frameworks modernes comme React, Vue.js, et Next.js, JavaScript me permet de :

- Créer des interfaces utilisateurs riches et dynamiques.
- Gérer des états complexes avec des outils comme Redux ou Zustand.
- Rendre mes applications performantes grâce au rendu côté serveur (SSR) ou au rendu statique (SSG).

## Mon stack actuel

Voici un aperçu des outils que j’utilise aujourd’hui pour développer des applications web modernes :

- **Frontend** : React.js + Typescript avec Tailwind CSS pour un design rapide et flexible.
- **Backend** : Plus des technologies Headeless comme **Sanity**
- **Base de données** : PostgreSQL selon les besoins du projet.
- **Déploiement** : Vercel ou Netlify pour le frontend, et AppWrite ou Neon pour le backend.

## Minimalisme et productivité

En 2023, j’ai adopté une approche minimaliste dans mon stack. Je privilégie les outils simples et efficaces, ceux qui me permettent de rester productif sans me perdre dans des configurations interminables. Par exemple :

- **Tailwind CSS** remplace les bibliothèques lourdes comme Bootstrap.
- **React js** puis **Nextjs** pour lancer rapidement un projet.
- **Postman** ou **Hoppscotch** pour tester mes API.

## Conclusion

Mon évolution de PHP à JavaScript reflète bien l’évolution du développement web en général. En adoptant des outils modernes, j’ai gagné en efficacité et en flexibilité. Cependant, je n’oublie pas mes bases, car elles m’aident encore à résoudre des problèmes complexes. Et vous, quelle est votre stack de développement préférée ?

document.title: Construire des applications avec Appwrite : Un backend tout-en-un
document.summary: Découvrez comment utiliser Appwrite pour construire un backend rapide et puissant pour vos applications web et mobiles.

body.raw:
Appwrite est une solution Backend-as-a-Service (BaaS) qui simplifie le développement d'applications modernes en fournissant un ensemble complet de services backend, comme l'authentification, la gestion des bases de données, le stockage des fichiers et bien plus encore. Contrairement à d'autres solutions de backend, Appwrite permet aux développeurs de se concentrer sur la logique métier, tout en gérant l'infrastructure à partir d'une interface simple et intuitive.

Dans cet article, nous allons explorer pourquoi Appwrite est un excellent choix pour vos applications, comment démarrer rapidement avec Appwrite, et comment interagir avec ses API.

## Pourquoi choisir Appwrite ?

### Backend complet et flexible

Appwrite fournit une large gamme de fonctionnalités prêtes à l'emploi, ce qui vous permet de vous concentrer sur le front-end de votre application tout en bénéficiant d'un backend complet. Parmi les fonctionnalités disponibles, on trouve :
- **Authentification** : Gère les connexions et l'inscription des utilisateurs via des emails, des mots de passe, ou des services tiers comme Google et GitHub.
- **Base de données** : Une base de données NoSQL flexible pour stocker et gérer vos données d'application.
- **Stockage de fichiers** : Vous pouvez stocker, organiser et servir des fichiers via une API simple.
- **Fonctions cloud** : Pour exécuter des logiques backend personnalisées avec Appwrite Functions.
- **Notifications push** : Envoi de notifications en temps réel aux utilisateurs de votre application.

### Facilité d'intégration

Appwrite offre une API RESTful robuste et une SDK pour plusieurs langages et frameworks. Il vous permet de commencer rapidement, même si vous n'avez pas une grande expérience en gestion de backend.

### Auto-hébergement ou Cloud

Appwrite est open source et peut être auto-hébergé sur vos serveurs ou vous pouvez choisir de l'utiliser dans le cloud via le service Appwrite Cloud, ce qui vous donne la flexibilité de choisir la méthode qui correspond le mieux à vos besoins.

## Comment démarrer avec Appwrite ?

### Prérequis

Avant de commencer, vous devez installer Appwrite sur votre machine locale ou utiliser une instance cloud Appwrite. Pour installer Appwrite localement, vous pouvez utiliser Docker. Voici la commande pour démarrer Appwrite dans un conteneur Docker :

```bash
docker run -d -p 80:80 -v /var/www/html:/usr/share/nginx/html appwrite/appwrite

document.title: COVID-19 Dashboard
document.summary: Open source analytics dashboard built with Django with over 200k visitors.
document.longSummary: Open source analytics dashboard built with Django with over 200k visitors. The dashboard provided a comprehensive and interactive overview of the COVID-19 pandemic.

body.raw:
### About the Project

This project was created to provide a comprehensive and interactive overview of the COVID-19 pandemic. The dashboard was built using Django and Plotly.js, and featured a fully interactive map made using Mapbox. The project was open source and received over 200k visitors, but the most rewarding part was the collaboration with contributors across the world.

<Image
  src="/projects/covid/tablet.png"
  alt="COVID-19 Dashboard"
  width={2580}
  height={1691}
  caption="Tablet view of the dashboard's home page. The application is designed to be responsive to all platforms and devices."
  contained
  size="lg"
/>

### Mobile first design

I designed the dashboard with a mobile-first approach, ensuring that the application was responsive to all platforms and viewports. Thankfully plotly and Mapbox are already mobile responsive to multi touch interactions so it was just a matter of ensuring the overall layout was adaptable.

<Image
  src="/projects/covid/phones.png"
  alt="COVID-19 Dashboard"
  width={1905}
  height={1409}
  caption="Mobile view of application, including list of key statistics, the map of daily growth, and the fully interactive map made using Mapbox."
  contained
  size="lg"
/>

### Read more

Here is a [blog post](https://b-r.io/blog/covid) that goes more in depth on how this was built

<Image
  src="/projects/covid/floating.png"
  alt="COVID-19 Dashboard"
  width={2580}
  height={1691}
  contained
  size="lg"
/>

document.title: Hines App Dev
document.summary: Designing and developing software used for management of $90b in assets.
document.longSummary: At Hines I've been responsible for building out full stack web applications at scale. Which are used internally for management of over $90b in assets. Here are some of the standout projects and features I've contributed to.

body.raw: The following projects are private and internal, so unfortunately I'm unable to show live demos or code specifics. However, I'll do my best to provide a high level overview of the projects and my role in them! ### About Hines Hines is a leading global real estate investment manager. We own and operate $93.2 billion¹ of assets across property types and on behalf of a diverse group of institutional and private wealth clients. Every day, our 5,000 employees in 30 countries draw on our 65-year history to build the world forward by investing in, developing, and managing some of the world’s best real estate. ## A Fresh New Approach When I joined the team at Hines, I saw an opportunity to improve the user experience of our flagship app. Despite the app's potential and its hundreds of active users, the existing design was outdated and the branding was inconsistent. I took the initiative to redesign the app from the ground up, introducing a new design system and a fully fledged UI/UX redesign. The new design was modern, clean, and consistent, and could be applied to other applications. It was well received by the users and the stakeholders. ### Introducing Figma As part of the redesign process, I introduced Figma as a design tool to the team. Starting with a fresh empty canvas, I built components from scratch, and began defining our new color palette, typography, and iconography. This was crucial to have our app look less like a Bootstrap 4 template and more like a custom commercial application. Training the team on how to use Figma helped us to collaborate better and completely changed the way we design and develop applications. It also removed the need for us to hire contractors for design work, making our process more efficient and cohesive. ### Introducing React and Next.js Initially, our team used Django for data management and workflows in several applications. As our team and applications grew, we faced limitations with Django's Jinja templating system, especially regarding interactivity and user experience. When tasked with building a new application, I chose to use Next.js for the front end while keeping Django for the backend (having used in hobby projects). This combination allowed us to retain Django's server-side rendering and performance benefits while enhancing interactivity and user experience with React's features. The benefits were immediate: - **Component-Based Architecture**: React's encapsulated components simplify complex UIs and make code predictable and debuggable. - **Hybrid Rendering**: Allows us to choose between server-side rendering, static site generation, and client-side rendering based on the use case. - **Performance**: Next.js's optimized build process and automatic code splitting improve performance and SEO. - **Developer Experience**: React's declarative syntax and component-based architecture make development faster and more enjoyable. - **Community and Resources**: React's large developer community and abundant resources provide readily available solutions. --- ## The Global Data Hub App The global data hub or GDH is our flagship application. It's used by hundreds of users and groups across different company regions and is responsible for outlining the very structure of the companies investment pipeline. All the way from initial project proposal, voting, funding, and closing of the deal. What started as a single CRUD workflow for the real estate investment pipeline has grown into a full fledged data management platform. ## Koko: Our new AI platform With the advent of AI and machine learning, we saw an opportunity to improve our data management and analysis capabilities. I was tasked with building a new platform that will hold a collection of AI models and tools that can be used by our team to from public-facing content generation to internal data analysis. Since AI is a complex topic in itself, I emphasized the importance of and intuitive user experience and simplicity in the design. This is something that I believe [OpenAI](https://openai.com) did an amazing job with their ChatGPT product design.

document.title: Gatsby.js Medium Blog
document.summary: Blog website built with Gatsby JS inspired by Medium design.

body.raw:
<Image
  src="/projects/medium/og.png"
  alt="og"
  width={2267}
  height={1280}
  size="lg"
  contained
/>

This is a gatsby portfolio template inspired by Mediums earlier design. A perfect fully featured starting point for your blog or portfolio.

### Features

- 📲 PWA ready, installable on Android and iOS
- 🔎 Algolia Search, search by all attributes
- 📧 Getform.io contact form with easy setup.
- 📝 Blog ready, easily add your blog posts with MDX
- 🌗 Togglable dark mode
- 💻 SEO ready, option to Add meta description

### Adding your blog posts

Adding your own content is super simple with the Jamstack design of the project. You won't need to write any HTML or CSS, just markdown (although you absolutely can if you wish to change the design or add your own features). The MDX posts are found in the content/posts/ directory. With MDX you can even add react components to your posts as found below.

<Image
  src="/projects/medium/phones.png"
  alt="2"
  width={3062}
  height={2042}
  caption="Mobile view, featuring detail view of a blog post, list view of blog posts, a seamless contact form, and a page to showcase gear with affiliate links."
  size="lg"
  contained
/>

<Image
  src="/projects/medium/tablet.png"
  alt="3"
  width={2267}
  height={1280}
  caption="Blog post's transform responsively to fit the screen. Sidebars for navigation and meta data are then shown."
  size="lg"
  contained
/>

### Dark mode ready

with a toggle switch in the header. The theme is saved in local storage so it will persist between sessions. or you can set it to follow the user's system settings.

<Image
  src="/projects/medium/dark computer.png"
  alt="5"
  width={5412}
  height={3246}
  size="lg"
  contained
/>

<Image
  src="/projects/medium/light computer.png"
  alt="4"
  width={5412}
  height={3246}
  size="lg"
  contained
/>
